children.subject: Oh, also there are a lot of startups that may offer unpaid internships. I strongly recommend against taking these since the standard in the tech industry (assuming that's what your startup is) is to pay pretty well, especially if it's in a high cost-of-living area.

The startup I'm joining wants me to propose my own project, do you have any advice on good places to search for inspiration or how ambitious I should be? They're a video game startup so I'm think either I want to work on maybe some aspect of the game specifically. They also want me to make my own program for my internship which worries me a little because I've never had an internship and I'm not sure what a day in the life or program seems. From reading articles online I'm thinking I should try some project with a set mentor or two and at the end of the program present my work but I don't know it all seems very vague right now lol

Also thank you so much for your advice it- definitely helps! how much time did you spend learning about the code and technology the companies used/ramp-up time and should I ask the startup what kind of software they use so I can get started on learning some of it?

well it's not quite an offer- they basically told me my weaknesses and points to improve, and advised me on getting a first internship at some other place, but that they'd be willing to take me on after some experience or either now if I can think of something productive for me to do

Not to scare you too much, but I would feel a little put off from this if a startup said to me that they would hire me if "I can think of something productive" to do. It seems a little too casual to me and it makes me feel like something is a little off.

If they're not willing to work with you to come up with a project, it might be a good indicator that they won't spend much time to help/mentor you during the internship. But yes, I think that generally summer intern projects are fairly self-contained projects that have potential to be completed within the span of the internship, with one or two mentors there to answer your questions. I don't have much advice for picking a specific project here.

As far as learning a company's tech stack ahead of time, they'll probably tell you what technologies they're using if you ask them after signing a non-disclosure agreement (NDA). Then it's really just up to you whether you want to dedicate unpaid pre-internship time to read up on it. To keep a healthy view of work-life balance, don't think of doing unpaid work as the norm.

First internship was at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland, and I got that by applying through NASA's online OSSI application. I worked on a web app (mostly front end, some back end), but I didn't receive too much technical mentorship because my mentor was not a front end developer. I had lots of freedom to make the project what I wanted it to be. I had a fun experience there exploring the NASA campus and touring Washington DC (other than the humidity/heat). The biggest things I learned were that web dev was not where I wanted to be in the long term (this was pretty valuable insight) and that the federal government was not where I wanted to be in the long term (although I was pretty sure of this prior to the internship).

Second internship was at General Motor's Cruise Automation in San Francisco, and I was referred there by a person I knew through my NASA internship (turns out networking is maybe somewhat important). I really enjoyed my time there, and I had a ton of independence on the research-y project that I worked on. The biggest things I learned there were what working in SF is like, what startup culture and tech industry are like, and that I kinda enjoy machine learning problems but that I might not enjoy working on applied machine learning in the long term.

I would recommend that you apply to everything that is remotely interesting to you to keep your options as open as possible. You shouldn't expect to be able to get into any particular company. If you already have an offer from the startup, I'd say go for it if a) you're interested in what the startup does, b) they offered you interesting sounding work, and c) they seem at least somewhat reputable. By going to a startup over a big company, you definitely give up some things, like the name recognition on your resume, the structure of the internship program (which I don't think is necessarily a huge minus because you may be treated more like any other employee in a less structured program, which is a good experience to have), and networking with the greater number of employees who have worked at and will work at other big name companies. But if you like what the startup is doing, I think it will be worth it to go.

Free free to reply with any questions
I knew someone who worked at a big tech company and he hooked me up with my first internship

history.content: What was your first internship, how'd you get it, what'd you work on/or either how much work was it and how was the mentorship/how much independence did you have? What expectations did you having going into it? Basically what was your experience and the biggest thing you learned? I'm curious because I've never had an internship and am thinking about working with a startup but don't know what to expect and they don't have a program for first/second years so I just don't really know much or if I should look for an internship with a more structured environment.
